lines.text: [Mr. Watson kisses his little girl through Mr. Smith's walkie-talkie]
Kisses to you.
No. Kisses to you.
Kisses to you, Sweetpea.
[when Mr. Smith takes the walkie-talkie out of Mr. Watson's hand]
[Mr. Smith tells Mr. Watson a story about a man he loved]

There was this guy... Big guy, Irish-Italian. Red-faced, black-haired, jolly son of a bitch... Wait a second, nobody could make me laugh like him. He made a science of collecting jokes. We closed more bars together than I could count. Now, he was a pal. I loved the crazy mick. I'm not ashamed to say that, but... He was a fuck-up. He had this image of himself. He thought he was a con man. Always trying to shave the edge. He was nickel and dime. I'll always miss him. Tell me why.
Tell you why, what?
Tell me why I miss him.
He's dead?
That's right. He is dead, but tell me why.
How do I know? I don't...
Tell me why he's dead.
Because you killed him.

That's right, I did. I killed him. He fucked up one too many times. So, I put a bullet in his eye. Then, I put two more into him just to make sure. Now, that was somebody I loved; I loved him! But I got the call, and I put him down like a sick animal. So... if you got doubts... about what's going to happen if you don't deliver, let me tell you something. I'll make gravy out of your little girl just to season that Black Irish cocksucker's meat. Now, you do what you're supposed to do, young man. You do it now.
[Mr. Smith and Ms. Jones look out for the perfect couple to kidnap]

[Ms. Jones comments on some rollerbladers]
Oh, man, I hate rollerbladers. Skateboarders I don't mind, even though they dress like fuckin' idiots. But when I see some pinhead on rollerblades, it really gives me the urge to want to grease the front of my car with them.
[Mr. Watson arrives at the train station in San Francisco]
Lynn, honey! Lynn! Don't run off now, Sweetpea. Stay close to daddy.
Okay.
We made it.
We made it.
[Ms. Jones grabs Mr. Watson's daughter and starts walking away with her]
Ma'am! I'll take my daughter.
Don't worry. My partner's good with kids.
[Mr. Smith tells Mr. Watson his mission to kill the woman in the picture]
You're out of your mind.
What's your point?
[first lines]

[Mr. Watson hears the train conductor shoutout to the Amtrak travelers]
Los Angeles is next! Los Angeles is next! Please check under your seats.
[Ms. Jones points out to Mr. Smith an old couple to kidnap]

[Ms. Jones points to an arguing couple]
That one... right there?
No. Hates his wife.
[Ms. Jones points out to Mr. Smith a few more different couples to kidnap]
What about them... right there?
Too old.
Oh. Them?
You ever had an idea, it would die of malnutrition. Leave it to me. I know people. It's my job... People person.
[Mr. Watson asks his daughter if she's ever seen him and her mom kiss]
Hey. Listen to me. It's alright to talk about it. You know that, don't you? All right, so tell me something. You never once saw your mom and I kiss like that?
No way.
Not once? How did you see us kiss?

[Lynn kisses the top of her hand real quick]
That's it? That 'mwah,' that little peck of a kiss? Honey, you missed a whole lot of kissing.
[Mr. Watson trips the men on rollerblades that are picking on his little girl]

[the men trip to the floor]
That's why you should always wear a helmet and knee pads. Because you never know when you're going to fall down and go boom. Right?
Right.
[Mr. Smith sees Mr. Watson and his little girl as the perfect pair to kidnap]

[in a low voice]
Perfect.
Perfect.
[Ms. Jones carries Lynn out of the train station as she steals a coloring book on the way out]
You stole that.
No, I didn't. I confiscated it. There's a difference.
No there's not.
[Mr. Watson and his little girl sit in the van with Mr. Smith and Ms. Jones]
I want my daddy!
Well, your daddy's right there.

[Mr. Watson from the passenger seat]
Daddy's right here, honey. Daddy's here.
We're your daddy's friends.

[Mr. Smith from the driver seat]
That's right. Policeman's your friend. Isn't that right, daddy? Daddy?
That's right, honey. The police are our friends.
[Mr. Smith threatens Mr. Watson by hitting his pistol in his leg]
Mr. Watson, you're not paying attention. Your daughter's life depends on you. Do you understand?

[Mr. Smith hits his pistol in Mr. Watson's leg again]
Ahh!
Do you understand that?
[Mr. Smith tells Mr. Watson the deadline he has to kill the woman in the picture]
00... I call my partner. Your daughter's dead. What happens if I don't call you?
Kill her anyways.
You hear that, Mr. Watson? Do you understand? It's the woman in the picture or your daughter.
God.
God can't help you Mr. Watson, only you.
[Lynn asks Ms. Jones where her dad is leaving to]
Where's my daddy going?
Your daddy's going to help the police. He's going to be a hero.
Like Power Rangers?

[Ms. Jones pats on Lynn's head]
Yeah, just like Power Rangers.
30 his little girl is dead]
30, my little girl is dead.' Say it! Say it! Name it!
30, my little girl is dead.
Unless you do what you're told. You go do it.
[Mr. Smith pushes Mr. Watson along to start walking]
Don't forget! I'll be watching you!
[the Hackney cab driver asks Mr. Watson for his $3.50]
Well, I'd like to hear about your problem, but the ride's over. That will be $3.50. I hope your problem doesn't have anything to do with my $3.50?
[Mr. Watson sees the giant poster for the re-elect Governor Eleanor Grant]

[as he slides the picture out of the envelope of the same woman]
Oh, shit.
[Mr. Watson asks Mr. Smith who is he]
Who are you?

[Mr. Smith whispers in his ear]
I'm the guy who'll kill your daughter if you don't get moving.
[Mr. Smith yells at Mr. Watson when he has a chance to shoot the Governor in the elevator]
She was right in front of you! What is wrong with you?

[Mr. Smith punches Mr. Watson in the stomach]
Are you fucking with me? Are you fucking with me?
[Mr. Smith loads Mr. Watson's gun for him]
All right. It's loaded. It's ready for the hunt. So are we.
[Mr. Watson walks past Mr. Huey the shoe shiner for the first time]
You having a rough day? Down at the heels, as they say? You don't see your face, you don't pay. What you need is a shoe shine. Shoe shine today.
[Mr. Watson sits down and meets Huey the shoe shiner]
Come on. Take 10. Take a break. Take a load off. Put the world in perspective. So... are you a visitor?
No. No, I'm just visiting.
Oh, yeah? So what do you do, if I may be so bold.
[Mr. Watson tells Mr. Huey that he's an accountant]
I'm an accountant.
Well, don't denigrate yourself, my friend. Where would the government be without accountants, huh? They wouldn't know how hard they could squeeze us until we popped. Isn't that right?
[Mr. Watson tries to tell Mr. Huey about his daughter]

[Mr. Watson whispers]
Sir. Sir... I need your help.
What was that? You have to speak up.

[Mr. Watson talks low]
There's a little girl in a van. She's my daughter.
I'm a little deaf in this ear. I mean, between that and my wooden leg, I'm all messed up. Compliments of the United States Army artillery corps.
[Mr. Watson opens the door to the van and sees his daughter asleep in front of Ms. Jones]
What we have here is what they call a Mexican stand-off.

[Mr. Watson cocks his gun at Ms. Jones]
Now, the thing you've got to ask yourself is, what's behind the seat?

[Mr. Watson sees Ms. Jones poke the muzzle of her gun from behind the seat]
Now, a .22 will go right through it, but even a button will throw a .22 off. So, there is a good chance that it can get screwed up somewhere along the way and miss the target. What about a .38? Well, a .38 will drill pretty straight unless of course it hits metal. Then it's going to bust up into bitty little pieces. It'll keep going, but it's going to get slowed down quite a bit. How's about a .357? Well, that'll go through the seat, her, the dashboard. Shit! It'll go through the entire engine block before it even knows it hit anything. It'll end up in some pedestrian three blocks away. What do you think? Huh? What is my poison?
[Mr. Watson looks back down at his little girl and the gun poking from behind the seat]
[Mr. Smith stops Mr. Watson from going to a police officer]
I know what you're thinking. You're like a worm on a hook, wiggling around, thinking you might get off.
What would you do?
She'd be dead. Do what you're supposed to do, young man! You do it now!
[Mr. Watson tells Officer Trust that there's a plot to kill the Governor]
Officer?
Yeah?
There's a plot to kill the Governor. If you don't believe me, check that man right there. He has a gun.

[Mr. Smith smiles from a distance, as Officer Trust whispers to Mr. Watson]
So do you, Mr. Watson.
[Officer Trust asks Mr. Smith if he's got the situation under control]
You got this under control, Smitty?
Yeah.
Sure doesn't look like it.
It's under control.
Yeah. Well, it better be, because I'm running out of these.
[Officer Trust gives Mr. Smith a new walkie-talkie]
[Mr. Watson throws away Mr. Smith's walkie-talkie]
I ought to throw you after that walkie-talkie, but I'm going to give you a break, because you're an amateur.
[Mr. Watson asks help from the Governor's assistant Krista Brooks]
You know something? My wife always said that I had a problem trusting people.

[Ms. Brooks smiles]
Well, you can trust Eleanor Samara Grant.
Well, I'm going to trust you.

[Mr. Watson pulls out his gun on Ms. Brooks]
And you're going to trust me.
[Mr. Watson and Ms. Brooks hand over their only gun to the Mystery Man]
Is it real? I mean, do we know anything about it?
It looks real. I don't know anything about guns.
May I see it?
The gun is real.

[the mystery man scoffs]
Well, it certainly looks real.

[as the mystery man looks over to the corner of the room]
May we have your opinion?

[the mystery man then hands over the gun to Mr. Smith]
You're supposed to be the expert in these matters.

[Mr. Smith checks the gun, grabs a pillow, and shoots Ms. Brooks dead]
Yeah. I'd say it's real.
[Mr. Watson sees Mr. Smith in a dream sequence after shooting him dead]
I killed you.
You fucked up.
[Mr. Smith blames Mr. Watson for the death of Ms. Brooks]

[as they stand over the dead body]
Look at her. That's what it looks like. She was alive a minute ago, and now she's dead because you wouldn't do what I told you to do.
[Mr. Smith stands over Mr. Watson's body in the elevator when a couple try to walk in]
Security force. Take the next car. Thank you.
[Mr. Watson tries to still convince Mr. Huey about the Governor assassination]
Listen, something's going to happen. When it's over with, you'll know what I was talking about.

What? The end of the world? Look man, don't give me your crazy rap. I'm not a bartender, I don't want to hear it. I raise a family doing this bullshit. Do me a favor? Get your white ass out of my chair. Big tip doesn't give you the right to crap in my ear.
[Officer Trust notices that Mr. Smith loses Mr. Watson again]
Where is he? Did you lose him?

[in a low voice]
Shut up.
[Mr. Huey comes up with a plan for Mr. Watson to change clothes with the guest service employee Gustino]
Hey, quick. Quick. Off with the shoes and pants. Trade with Gustino.
What are you talking about?
Don't worry about it.

[as Mr. Huey sees the two stand quiet looking at each other]
Oh, no time to be shy ladies. Come on, do what I tell you.
[Mr. Watson confronts Governor Eleanor Grant for the first time]
Wait a minute, I know you. You're from the elevator.
That's right.
You were very nervous.

[as Mr. Watson holds his gun on her]
Guns tend to make me very nervous.
[Lynn keeps noticing how Ms. Jones looks to check on her]
Why do you keep looking at me?
It's my job. I'm your babysitter.
I'm not a baby.
Oh, you're a big girl?
I'm not a big girl, but I'm not a baby.
[Brendan Grant combs the hair of Governor Eleanor Grant after he thinks she's been shot]
A bleeding heart makes a very big target, Governor.
[as Governor Grant opens her eyes]
[Mr. Smith fights with Mr. Watson and slams him against a concrete wall]
Fuck with me, huh? Huh?
[Mr. Huey startles Ms. Jones as he begins to clean her van windshield]
Hey, what-what are you doing?

[Mr. Huey sprays and wipes her windshield]
I'm just giving you the gift of a clean windshield.
No, no, I don't want my windshield clean. So, just get out of here.
Oh, you just think you don't want your windshield clean.
No, I know that I don't want my windshield cleaned. So, get out of here.
Oh, come on. Don't be like that. Just think of me as the Moses of dirty windshields, leading you through the desert of dead bugs.
[Mr. Huey chuckles]
[Mr. Huey demands Ms. Jones for his $1 after cleaning her van windshield]
I've already done it. I've already done it. You have to pay me now.
I ain't paying you nothing!
Oh, come on. You want to deny me a lousy dollar. After I've sweated like a pig giving you the gift of a clean windshield?
Fucking-A!
[Mr. Watson fires his gun at the back of Mr. Smith]
Very good, Mr. Watson. I told them, I can make a killer out of you.
[as Mr. Watson fires his gun at Mr. Smith]
[Mr. Huey knocks out Ms. Jones with his fake leg]

[as he kisses the wing tip of his fake leg]
Nothing like a good wing tip.
[chuckling]
[last lines]

[the JBN reporter tells of the story about the bizarre attack on Governor Eleanor Grant]
Just minutes ago, shots were fired at Governor Grant. The police are just beginning to arrive on the scene. The details of the attempted assassination continue to pour in. This is going to prove to be one of the most bizarre stories of the year. Our sources are now pin-pointing a conspiracy which could point as high as Brendan Grant, Governor Grant's husband. This is a bizarre case, and we will give over to you any details, late breaking events, as we get them. Stephen Shuster, JBN.
